Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2008 03:48PM ndaoust wrote: I like that - Feb Fighters!  Maybe if we call ourselves that, I will actually feel like a fighter.  I too am overwhelmed and feeling sad.  I wish I could give you a hug {{{nowwhat}}}.  I too really dislike feeling this low, and I know it takes a toll on those around me. We will get through this, and hopefully we can laugh at ourselves for all this wasted energy worrying, being anxious, etc. nolana

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2008 07:51PM ndaoust wrote: Well, what a day.  I have zero energy and my body hurts like the flu.  I am able to eat, but nothing tastes good.  I am feeling better as the evening comes, so hopefully I will make it to work tomorrow even if just for a little while. Ladies, just remember to take your meds, eat as you can and rest.  That is what is getting me through this most uncomfortable day! hugs, nolana

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2008 06:06PM ndaoust wrote: Hey everyone! I am actually feeling human today!  I made it to work and am making it through the day okay.  I'm a bit bleery-eyed, but other than that I think I am on my way to returning to normal.  I actually slept last night for the first time since taking the steroids last week.  What a wonderful feeling. I'm keeping all of you in my thoughts. Hugs, nolana

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2008 11:11PM ndaoust wrote: Okay, I have to laugh.  As soon as I ask you all about the hair, mine starts falling out in clumps.  So I invited my mom and a few friends over for Wed night to shave it.  I figure at least I can do this part on MY terms, not the cancer's.  (Oh yeah, today is my 37th birthday - one I'll never forget!) I so enjoy reading your posts and look forward to hearing how you all are doing (both good and bad), feels like family. Keep the faith, Hugs, nolana

So, we are getting ready for my head shaving party.  DH is being wonderful - he's cooked up some really good nachos.  My friends are bringing wine and other goodies, and for dessert we have chocolate covered strawberries.  I just hope I can get through this without crying LOL!!! Welcome to the "newbies," keep coming back - this is a great group who have really helped me in the bad moments. Take care all! hugs, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2008 06:01PM ndaoust wrote: For what it's worth:  here's my thoughts on the constant spotting or many periods:  The chemo makes us anemic, so when the layer starts to grow in the uterus, it runs out because we have reduced clotting ability.  I had two periods in Feb, and spotted for weeks.  I am finally having a couple days where I don't have to wear protection.  Take care all! hugs, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 10:56PM ndaoust wrote: Hi everyone, Tx 2 went well, although I was immediately tired and totally wiped out today.  Spent most of the day sleeping, although tonight I am up playing on the computer.  I am having some issues with nausea, and things take really salty. Oh... my eyelashes are falling out in clumps.  Has anyone tried using fake ones?  Or does the eyeliner work the best? Hugs, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 12:33PM ndaoust wrote: Di53 - hang in there sweetie.  I went through several weeks of feeling very alone and sad, crying all the time.  Let the tears come out.  A friend told me to think of the tears as getting the bad stuff out of your body.  After that, I didn't mind crying so much. And yes, it does take time getting used to accepting help from others.  I'm sorry you don't feel support from your daughter - I have a friend, we've been friends since we were 18 months old.  She avoids me now and that hurts.  Write when you feel sad and upset.  That's what we are here for. hugs, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 05:33PM ndaoust wrote: Hi everyone, Well, round 3 really knocked me down.  I hate what the chemo does to us, both physically and mentally/emotionally.  I am lucky in that I have a great support system, but there were times this last weekend that I was positive I wasn't going to do #4.  Then I remember how many of you have done much, much more than this and I just need to suck it up and get through it.  With the Feb Fighters I will! I had an episode of lymphedema a couple weeks ago.  I went for a massage and conveniently forgot to remind her not to touch my left arm.  I finally see a physical therapist tomorrow about this.  I'll let you know what I learn.  It's gotten a lot better, but today my arm is sore and tight.  Grrr... I'm mad at myself for this boo-boo! The itching I asked about went away when I remember to take my final dose of steroids.  And I have been taking Claritin or Benedryl to help with the itching as I guess it's an allergic reaction to the Taxotere.  My fingertips are really sore today, and I noticed some discoloration along all the nail beds that are growing out.  It's like a bruise, but in a line. Tonight I am going to the ACS Look Good Feel Better class.  I am taking some scarves with me so I can learn how to tie them.  I do have some hair growing back, but it's really sparse and sticks straight out since it's about 1/4 of an inch long. Take care all! hugs, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 06:52PM ndaoust wrote: Hi everyone, Tomorrow is treatment 4 - the last one.  I had a really hard time with #3, so I am preparing for the worst and hoping for the best.  Regardless, it is the last one - yahoo!! I saw a plastic surgeon (second opinion), and with my mild lymphedema and many seromas (fluid accumulation at the mastectomy site), he will not take tissue from my back to build a breast mound.  My tummy is out, so I'm left with the expander under the skin and muscle, followed by an implant.  Do any of you know anyone who has done reconstruction this way?  I'd love to hear what they think of it.  I will search the other message boards for more information. Hugs to all, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 11:18PM ndaoust wrote: Oh yeah - my oncologist is not prescribing Nuelasta or Nupogen (sp?).  She explained that my immune system will dip, but I will still be protected.  HOWEVER, I am to stay away from sick people, and keep my hands away from my face until I can wash them after touching anything that might have been touched by someone else (door knobs, staircase railings, etc).  I work in infection control, so I do this anyway to make sure I don't pick up someone else's bug. So ladies, keep those alcohol hand degermer gels handy (greater than 61% alcohol).  They kill more bugs on your hands, and keep killing for a while after you use it.  Most have added stuff so your hands don't dry out.  Of course, if you hands are visibly dirty, you are going to eat, or you just used the bathroom, wash with soap and water. Now, if I get sick or run a fever, we will revisit the Neulasta/Nupogen topic. nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 03:55PM ndaoust wrote: Hi Everyone, Well, tomorrow treatment #2 for me.  My mom and husband remind me that then I'll be half way done.  I remind them I start counting after the side effects go away.  Chris - that is my dream, to swim in the wild with the dolphins.  What a wonderful treat you enjoyed! Donna - My diagnosis still hasn't hit me yet.  I am waiting because I know it will, and it will hit hard.  I use the lint sheets that come on the roller.  Although they do hurt a bit.  I took an electric shaver to my head Saturday night, and it pulled a lot of the loose hairs out.  I have huge bald spots and then some spot with hair.  My hubby gave me a wonderful head rub last night - he's a massage therapist, and usually pulls my hair when he does this.  Aha!  Another silver lining!! Well, take care all!! Hugs, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2008 02:16AM ndaoust wrote: Hi Rose, sleeping is hard right now.  My body hurts, and that translated into one whopper of a nightmare.  My husband made me some soup and I took an ativan, so hopefully I'll calm down.  This time around I've spent 3 days in bed mostly.  I get up, do a few things, then go lay down again.  Tonight the joint aches and pains really started in.  The doc said motrin, and it helps.  I just hate the time it takes getting through this part.  :) So the stubbles need to come out too, eh?  Mine are being stubborn.  I guess I could dry duct tape? hugs, nolana

Hugs to all, nolana

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2008 01:46PM ndaoust wrote: I am glad to be a part of this group, and having you all makes this a bit easier to take.  Bee - I agree, good luck to us both!  We'll have to compare notes after the 21st. nowwhat - oh my, I laugh so hard when I read your post.  I love what your daughter said!  I wish I could describe the look on my husband's face when I told him the expander is hard like a baseball. Patricia - thank you, it helps knowing I'm not the only one who still has good cries.  Sometimes I feel like such a baby, but it is so very theraputic to get it out. Aurora - thanks for the details!!! Yes, we will make it through this road.  I read on another board last weekend that only the strongest women get breast cancer.  And from what I have read from you all, I'm beginning to believe it! nolana

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2008 04:55PM ndaoust wrote: So glad to know I am not the only one with emotions bouncing around.  People say to not get caught up in the "pity party" mode, so I begin to wonder if that is all I am concentrating on.  But at this point I can't really control my emotions, so I just let them out.  My mom is coming with me for the first part of the infusion, my husband will come later.  The chairs for them are not too comfortable, so I like how they are splitting the time.  My hubby will take me to work Thursday morning (I work on the 2nd floor of the hospital, my infusion is on the 3rd) just in case the anti-nausea/anxiety drugs make me too tired to drive. I'm anxious to hear from those who started Feb 14th - I thought there were a few? Gail - I hope you get rid of that sore throat & cough, and feel better soon! Hugs to all, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 05:51PM ndaoust wrote: Aurora - you are making me hungry.  I'm about to fly to you and raid your fridge (I'm in CA)!!!!  I'm glad you are doing so well this time around.  You give me hope that perhaps the first time will also be the worst. Patricia - that list is awesome.  I just realized the not having to pluck the hairs on my chinny-chin-chin last night.  Well... I plucked them but they came right out. Bridget - you can do this!  There have been times that I wonder if I can do this, yet somehow I make it through one more day.  And that one more day brings me closer to feeling better and being done with treatment.  Hang in there - we are here for you. Laura - I am going to try the massage idea.  I too believe in the power of the human touch.  Did you have a mastectomy/lymph node dissection?  If so, how do you handle this with the massage therapist? Okay ladies, now I have some questions for you: - when did you head hair start to fall?  I am waiting.... - have any of your noticed your fingernail beds beings sore? - I've been using Biotene mouthwash.  Does the baking soda help with the burned mouth feeling?  That seems to be the one side effect that is hanging on, and on. Hugs, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 04:39PM ndaoust wrote: Hi everyone, In re the wigs, I got a skull cap to wear under my wig when I purchased it.  I haven't tried it yet, but that may help alleviate some of your itchy issues. Personal stuff:  I'm 37, married to DH almost 4 years though we've been together 10.  I have my MPH in infectious diseases and currently work in infection control at a hospital.  I have a 15.5 year old stepson (who told me I look ridiculous bald - gotta LOVE the teen years).  A little over a year ago we were trying for our own, but obviously He has other plans for me.  When this all started, DH and I were having problems in our marriage, but he has really been the best support and comfort through all of this, which makes me hopeful for the future.  My other big support is my mom, it was she who buzzed my head.  I am so very lucky with the support I have found in my friends (okay, only SOME** of them) and the people I work with.  I wish I could spread that support to you all too! **I say SOME of them because my lifelong friend, who I have known since we were 18 months old, has been avoiding me like the plague since this all started.  But she wants to see me bald.  Hmm... I am not a circus show, you know?  hugs, nolana

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2008 03:50PM ndaoust wrote: Hi Everyone, I am starting chemo (TC) on Feb 21st, and I am scared to death.  I have been reading lots of your posts to get an idea of what to expect.  I know we are all different, and it is the fear of the unknown that scares me most, but.... I was diagnosed 11/21/07, IDC, 1cm, ER+/PR-/HER2-.  At first, we thought it was just DCIS, but then pathology found the tumor in the breast after my mastectomy on 12/10/07.  Lymph node dissection was 01/04/08, with 0/18.  My Oncotype DX score was 43, thus the chemo. So I'm here to travel this road with you.  These days I have been spending a lot of time crying.  Anyone else having the same reaction?  I feel like such a baby, but everyone around me tells me how strong I am.  Wish I could believe them! kisses & hugs, nolana

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2008 02:08PM ndaoust wrote: Aurora - thank you for your words of strength! I too am extremely nervous (and scared) as my first treatment is Thursday.  I'm not worried about the infusion, just what side effects I'm going to experience.  I know there are others with me on this journey, but for whatever reason I cannot seem to shake the anxiety & crying that comes with it!  I know I'm driving my husband and officemate crazy with my ups & downs. Hang in there everyone (as I tell myself the same thing!). nolana

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 12:51PM ndaoust wrote: Well ladies, treatment number 1 went just fine.  No problems finding a vein, with the infusion of the drugs, etc.  I made sure to take the Zofran ahead of time, and added some Ativan just to make comfortable.  When we were done, DH and I went to dinner.  About half-way through I just wanted to lay my head down and go to sleep.  Of course that didn't last very long - by 9pm the steroids had kicked in again and my mind was buzzing.  I took some more Ativan and did get some sleep. Today I am a bit queasy, a bit headachy, and very tired, but I did make in into work.  My mind seems to be okay - not too fuzzy yet! Gail, that's great news!  I too was not supposed to do chemo, but my Oncotype DX test came back with a 30% risk of recurrence in the next 10 years, my tumor was 1 cm, so that put me in the category of should do chemo.  Congrats!!! Hugs, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 09:16PM ndaoust wrote: Hey everyone, Things are a bit better everyday!  I am getting these bad headaches though, and my legs hurt at night.  Anyone else experiencing that?    I still get really tired about 2-3 in the afternoon (my day starts at 7:30), but am having problems falling asleep at night.  I have tried the Ativan to help me sleep, but it gives me really weird dreams.  I'm going to ask and see if my doc will give me something different that will help me sleep. I am noticing my hair is starting to fall out.  And I also realize I am ready and not ready for that to happen.... K - I too am only having 4 treatments.  And I do find it very interesting how each doctor does things their own way.  Patricia - what an AWESOME outing you had!!  Bravo to you and your angel! I wish you all a good night. hugs, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2008 11:48PM ndaoust wrote: Hey Bridget (and all) - although you've already been exposed to your son's infection, you can help protect yourself by wearing something over your nose & mouth, like a surgical mask or kerchief, when you are within 3 feet of your son (or anyone else who is sick).  That will help reduce your exposure, and hopefully your son isn't bothered by that. I did some research, and the worst time after chemo with TC for the immune system is 10-17 days after - that's when you hit your nadir or lowest low.  And, as my doc explained, your immune system is still working, just not as well.  So I will keep my fingers crossed that you will not catch his flu!!! Donna - congratulations, that is WONDERFUL news!  A new life always brings hope to everyone surrounding him/her. Grannie - glad you are feeling better tonight.  :) Artsie - my eyelashes and eyebrows have thinned, but I still have some.  And I still have hair, albeit stubbles, on my head.  I wish that hair would fully fall out already!  Oh yeah - I still have to shave my legs LOL!!! Everyone else - keep going Feb Fighters!! hugs to all, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 11:09PM ndaoust wrote: Hi everyone! Well, I am feeling pretty okay (I only teared up twice today, no actual crying!).  I guess the steroids are kicking in.  I hope I am feeling this good tomorrow - I actually feel like a fighter and not a crybaby for once! Bridget - hang in there.  I had 3 surgeries in less than 4 weeks:  Dec 10 I had my mastectomy, and that was supposed to be it.  Then pathology found the 1 cm invasive tumor, so I had to go back under for the lymph node dissection on Jan 4.  In between, on Christmas Eve, I had emergency spinal surgery because somehow I herniated a disc and couldn't walk.  I am still numb in my right leg and have lost some use of that leg/foot, but I can walk and drive, and I am finally without back pain, so I really can't complain. Anyway, I'm telling you this because your body is incredible and strong and you have to believe in it's healing powers.  This is something I have learned over the past few weeks/months. I have packed my chemo bag:  peppermint lifesavers, ginger candy, water, pretzels, reading materials, puzzle book, a journal and my Snoopy.  People keep telling me I need to write things down and journal this part of my life.  The problem is I hate writing!  I'm taking it with my anyway, it was a gift from a co-worker after I shared my diagnosis.  Maybe I'll actually write something in it. Turns out my mom won't be coming.    She got called to jury duty today and got seated for a case that will last two weeks in argument, plus deliberation.  If she gets out early, she'll stop by (how sweet!).  So DH gets to come for the entire time.  At this moment, I am planning to have a head shaving party and invite my friends to go through this experience with me.  We'll see if I'm this brave in two weeks.  I should start losing my hair 3-4 days after my 37th birthday... definitely a birthday I won't forget anytime soon. Well, I am actually feeling like I'm coming down off the steroid high, so I think I may try to get some sleep.  Hugs to you all, and I will keep the good thoughts and vibes going out to each and every one of you. hugs, nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2008 09:15PM ndaoust wrote: Hi everyone, Just checking in.  It's day 3, and WOW am I tired!  I've had some tummy upset, some headaches, but I am taking the meds as prescribed and so far doing just fine.  My mom and I went out for a couple hours this morning to check head coverings, went fabric shopping and then to lunch.  Then I came home and crashed and am looking forward to going back to bed soon! Nothing tastes right, and I'm hungry.  Such an interesting place to me LOL! Glad to see you all seem to be in good spirits - woohoo!  That's the February fighting spirit! Hugs and I hope you all sleep well tonight! nolana
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 10:58PM ndaoust wrote: Complain all you want!  I (we) totally understand!  Are you using Biotene mouthwash?  I have found all the Biotene stuff (toothpaste, mouthwash, gum) helps heal sore spots before they become sores. My doc doesn't do the neulasta shot, so I figured it was the taxotere.  It's supposed to cause neuropathy.  Wow, sometimes those shooting pains really hurt!  I do have some vicodin left over from my back surgery and took one last night.  I may do the same again tonight. hugs, nolana

Take care everyone, and thanks for listening to me whine.  hugs, nolana

I'm glad to hear you are all doing well. hugs, nolana

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2008 10:25PM ndaoust wrote: Hi Everyone, I actually enjoyed my first day being bald.  It's not bothering my like I thought it would! Crazypam - thanks for the b-day wishes.  Donna - cute about your hubby!  The party was great.  My mom did the honors, and at one point I had a mullet left.  My friends got a great laugh out of that.  Then the bangs were the last to go, so I looked pretty funny!  I bet you really made a difference for that woman you ran into at the shop.  A friend of mine has a co-worker whose wife is going through this too.  I have been passing along any tips and advice as I learn things.  I hope I am helping her. I am pooped tonight, but wanted to check in and say "Hi." Take care, Hugs, nolana

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2008 09:54PM ndaoust wrote: Hello Ladies! Well, treatment 2 hit fast and hard, and I spent most of 4 days in bed.  But I also seem to be recuperating just as fast.  I have a sore mouth/throat, got some magic mouthwash for that.  Still having problems sleeping, but that's because of the leg and back pain (and my brain not shutting down).  Today I noticed my nailbeds are sore again, and the skin around the edges of my nails is dry and peeling.  For the most part, no issues eating, just a lot of heartburn/acid indigestion, but then I did have Mexican for lunch. Someone asked about the hat I'm wearing in my picture.  It's a little knit hat that has tails that wrap 3 times around the head.  I got it here:  http://www.softhats.com/cancer-hat.php?sku=S516. And ladies I am walking for all of you in the Susan G. Komen Race for the Cure!!  I AM NOT soliciting for donations - I wanted to share my page so you can see my little dog Mistletoe, who will be walking with me wearing her pink harness and leash:  https://www.kintera.org/faf/donorReg/donorPledge.asp?ievent=265447&lis=1&kntae265447=C2E6A70174B24F658922B3200D7CA3E4&supId=207527976. Hugs to all, Nolana
